Reality in FL Setting: Clients' hardware varies significantly. More pronounced in the cross-device setting than the cross-silo setting.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods need to ..., otherwise the search will be delayed by low end devices or leave high end devices waiting in idle most of the time.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Every worker node can access all training data.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients can only access their local data.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods need to balance searching for a global architecture suited to most clients’ data or search for architectures personalized to each client’s data.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Training data is gathered at a central location.
Reality in FL Setting: Training data is distributed unevenly across clients
Resulting Class of Challenges: Since some clients generate more data than others, FedNAS methods need to ensure they are not overrepresented in the searched architecture.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: The training data is drawn from the same distribution.
Reality in FL Setting: Each client draws training data from their own distribution.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS need to be robust w.r.t. to non-i.i.d. data, which makes evaluating and ranking candidate architectures noisier than in the centralized setting.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes are equally and highly available.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients may only be available during certain times of day and some clients may be available a lot more than others.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods must prevent the search from being dominated by a the most active clients, otherwise the resulting architecture will be biased toward the data and capabilities of the most frequently available clients

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes communicate over high-bandwidth, low-latency links.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients typically communicate with the central server with high latency and low bandwidth.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS must be communication-efficient, otherwise exchanging model weights and architecture parameters becomes a bottleneck during search.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes are high-end machines with powerful CPUs, GPUs and large RAM.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients are edge devices with few computational resources.
Resulting Class of Challenges: The computational power required by some NAS methods makes them unfeasable for FedNAS. Additionally, units of computational work typically done on a single worker node, need to be split up across clients, making the FedNAS method implementation complex.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: All worker nodes participate in each iteration.
Reality in FL Setting: Only a subset of clients participate in each search iteration.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods must ensure that a realistic sample of the client population is represented in the architecture search.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes are inside the same trust domain.
Reality in FL Setting: All participating parties (i.e. the central server and clients) can consider another potentially malicious.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods need to deal with attacks from participating parties, such as poisoning of architecture parameter updates during search or inference of client data from architecture parameters [TODO: verify that’s possible].

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes reliably take part in the search process.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients can drop out of a communication round at any time and take long to complete their part of the search.
Resulting Class of Challenges: FedNAS methods need to handle client dropouts and stragglers, since interrupted or delayed evaluations of candidate architectures can slow down or destabilize the search process.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: The location of the search procedure is irrelevant because all computation happens at a central location.
Reality in FL Setting: For some NAS methods, the server can take part in the architecture search.
Resulting Class of Challenges: If applicable, FedNAS methods can integrate the server into the search process to speed up the search, but … why is this challenging?

FedNAS methods must balance global optimality with personalization, deciding whether to search for a single shared architecture, a family of architectures, or client-specific variants under federated constraints.
